title: Roberto Sensini
text:
Roberto Néstor Sensini (born 12 October 1966) is an Argentine <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and former player, who played as a <a href="centre-back">centre-back</a> or <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>. As a player with the <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina national team</a>, he won both the <a href="1991%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1991</a> and <a href="1993%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1993 Copa América</a>, also finishing in third place in the <a href="1989%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1989</a> edition of the tournament. He also represented his nation in the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990</a>, <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1994</a>, and <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1998 FIFA World Cup</a> finals, finishing in second place at the 1990 World Cup. Furthermore, he won an Olympic silver medal with Argentina at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">1996 Olympics</a>.
Club career.
His professional playing career started in 1986 for <a href="Newell%27s%20Old%20Boys">Newell's Old Boys</a>; where he won his first title before relocating to Italy in 1989, joining <a href="Udinese%20Calcio">Udinese Calcio</a> alongside compatriot <a href="Abel%20Balbo">Abel Balbo</a>. Sensini played four seasons for the "bianconeri", before moving to <a href="Parma%20F.C.">Parma</a> in 1993, where he remained for a further six seasons. During this period Sensini sometimes played in midfield and won two <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a>s, two <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Italian Cup</a>s, and the <a href="UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a> with the "gialloblu", also reaching the final of the <a href="European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">European Cup Winners' Cup</a> in <a href="1994%20UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%20Final">1994</a>. He would then have a brief stint with <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">S.S. Lazio</a> starting from the <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20Serie%20A">1999–2000 season</a>, winning the "<a href="Serie%20A">scudetto</a>", the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Italian Cup</a>, the <a href="1999%20UEFA%20Super%20Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a>, and the <a href="2000%20Supercoppa%20Italiana">Supercoppa Italiana</a> in his first season. After two years with the club, he moved back to <a href="Parma%20F.C.">Parma</a> for a further year, winning another <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> in 2002, before returning to his first Italian club, Udinese, in 2002.
In 2005, he was one of the most consistent performers in Udinese's surprise qualification for the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>. Sensini was one of the oldest players of the <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Serie%20A">2005–06 Serie A</a>, holding even the record as the oldest foreign player to score a goal in first division, at the age of 39 years, two months and 26 days. With over 380 matches at the top level, he was considered one of the most experienced defenders of the Italian league, and often nicknamed "nonno" (grandfather) by Italian sports journalists. He retired at the end of the season.
International career.
"Boquita" Sensini debuted for his <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">national team</a> in 1987, and played his last match in 2000. He played in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990</a>, <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1994</a> and <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1998</a>. In the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">1990 FIFA World Cup Final</a> Sensini conceded the disputed penalty kick from which <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a> scored their winning goal. He helped his country to a third-place finish at the <a href="1989%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1989 Copa América</a>, and he was also part of the championship teams in the <a href="1991%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1991 Copa América</a> and <a href="1993%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1993 Copa América</a> tournaments, as well as the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics">silver medal-winning team</a> at the <a href="1996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>, as one of the three over-23 players allowed per squad.
Style of play.
Sensini was a consistent, decisive, and intelligent player. He was also extremely tactically versatile, and was capable of playing in any <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defensive</a> or <a href="Midfielder">midfield</a> position. Throughout his career, he was deployed as a <a href="full-back%20%28association%20football%29">full-back</a>, an attacking <a href="wing-back%20%28association%20football%29">wing-back</a>, a <a href="centre-back">centre-back</a>, or even as a <a href="Central%20midfielder">central</a> or <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>. Although he primarily excelled defensively as a ball winner, due to his marking and tackling ability, as well as his tough, aggressive, and physical playing style, he was also a player with good technique, who was capable of making attacking runs and contributing offensively for his team with occasional goals. Considered one of the best players of the 1990s and 2000s.
Management career.
On 10 February 2006, after the dismissal of <a href="Serse%20Cosmi">Serse Cosmi</a>, Sensini ended his playing career and was appointed Udinese's new manager. He was supported in his new position by <a href="Loris%20Dominissini">Loris Dominissini</a>, who was named co-coach. The following month when Dominissini was sacked, Sensini resigned and left the club. Results had not improved with the team in danger of <a href="Promotion%20and%20relegation">relegation</a>, while they were defeated in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> by <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>n team <a href="PFC%20Levski%20Sofia">Levski Sofia</a>.
For the Argentine Torneo Clausura 2008, Sensini coached Estudiantes de La Plata, having replaced <a href="Diego%20Simeone">Diego Simeone</a>. Sensini then went to manage <a href="Newell%27s%20Old%20Boys">Newell's Old Boys</a> for the Clausura 2009 tournament. In April 2011, he resigned after two years as head coach of Newell's Old Boys after Lepra's sixth loss in nine games, leaving them 19th in the Clausura table.
On 21 February 2012, Sensini was appointed as the new head coach of Argentine first division club <a href="Col%C3%B3n%20de%20Santa%20Fe">Colón</a>. He resigned on 16 March 2013 after a 1–0 loss against rivals <a href="San%20Lorenzo%20de%20Almagro">San Lorenzo</a>, following a row of eight matches without winning.
Personal life.
In 1996 Sensini took <a href="Italian%20nationality%20law">Italian citizenship</a>. He is an <a href="Italian%20Argentine">Italian Argentine</a>, whose grandfather Pacifico Sensini emigrated from <a href="Macerata">Macerata</a> to <a href="Rosario%2C%20Santa%20Fe">Rosario, Santa Fe</a> in 1911.
